div.bibl: El Mexicano, Vol I. No 1. April 20, 1934.

body.p: With the approval of the Fraternal Evolution, Pan-American Association, Mexican Women's Club, C. L. R. Anahuac, 333 Cuauhtemoc, C. special meeting was called in which the above societies were represented. A discussion began in order to formulate mutual arrangements for a patriotic celebration and once for all avoid the lucrative aims of some of our countrymen who, without any scruple, have the name of our heroes in the pursuing of their own selfish interests. Such procedure has created many ailments, formentehatred, discord and increased the divisions which in the past have been so detrimental.
The meeting took place in the social residence of the Pan-American society and Club, 1129 So. Ashland Avenue, April 5, 1934. After the discussion of many plans the following was approved.

1. To form a permanent Pro-Patrias Committee and that this committee shall be composed of two delegates from each society or group in Chicago and suburbs. The mission of this committee will be to find the most adequate and convenient form to celebrate the most memorable in the history of Mexico. Therefore, the mercantilism will be eliminated from our national celebrations; they will do everything possible to inform the colony that in the holidays of our country there should be no speculation tolerated to inform of the obligations they have towards their heroes, those who fought and, at the cost of many sacrifices, conquered the sovereignty of the country no to us. 2. The treasurer of our Committee will be the Mexican North Wells Street, and any Mexican who wish to financially towards the celebration, may send his contribution directly to the Mexican Consulate.
That by the treasurer That all the reports public through effective our disposal. 3. The Committee shall publish a paper under the name El Mexicano.

Through this was shall inform the colony of the work done by the committee. Also it education of our countrymen 4. The officer of the Committee shall vice-chairman, secretary, assistant-secretary commissions as may be necessary. The officers will be elected for the period of year and the elections should take on April 5th, each year. The elections of those to be followed will be under the supervision of the Mexican Consul. 5. All the may render their services unconditionally. If any delegate should not comply with his duty, his society willasked to recall him send another in his place. The societies may leave their delegates permanently or change them if so desired.
